title: Nonorganic Hearing Loss with History of Mastoidectomy
chief_complaint: I haven't been able to hear out of my left ear since a tumor was removed in 2004. I also have pain in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Reported hearing loss onset in 2004 following ear surgery.
problem_summary.course: Stable reported loss since surgery; recent onset of otalgia.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear reported; Right ear reported as normal.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otalgia (Left > Right), reported tympanic membrane perforation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient reports she cannot hear from her left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing status and ear pain.

history.present_illness: Patient reports hearing loss in the left ear since 2004. Initially denied otalgia but later reported pain greater in the left ear than the right. Reports a perforation in the left TM.
history.otologic_history: History of childhood ear infections. Surgery in 2004 (patient reports tumor removal; ENT notes suggest mastoidectomy).
history.patient_goals: Assessment of hearing loss and pain.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows mild low-frequency SNHL rising to normal, then sloping to moderately severe in high frequencies. Left ear shows a highly erratic, 'sawtooth' configuration (profound to mild to profound) inconsistent with organic pathology. Reliability was poor; retesting showed significant threshold shifts and inconsistencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT agrees with PTA; WRS is good. Left ear SRT (53 dB) is in poor agreement with the calculated PTA (25 dB) and best thresholds. Left ear WRS is very poor.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Stenger test performed at 500 and 1000 Hz was positive, indicating false responses.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Not measured due to patient report of otalgia and history of surgery.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presented with a reported left-sided hearing loss. Initial testing revealed a highly erratic 'sawtooth' audiometric configuration in the left ear and a mild-to-moderately severe loss in the right ear. However, results were deemed unreliable due to significant inter-test inconsistencies, poor SRT-PTA agreement in the left ear, and a positive Stenger test at 500 and 1000 Hz, indicating nonorganic hearing loss. Medical imaging later confirmed ossicular discontinuity and otitis media.
counseling_points: Explain that the hearing test results today were inconsistent (e.g., speech hearing levels did not match tone hearing levels), making it difficult to determine the true hearing sensitivity.
Discuss the positive Stenger findings gently, indicating that the ear is detecting sound at softer levels than the voluntary responses suggest.
Recommend medical management for the reported ear pain and infection (otitis media) identified by the physician.
Emphasize the importance of consistent responses during the follow-up evaluation in 2 weeks to accurately plan for rehabilitation.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is somewhat defensive or vague about the hearing loss history.
During the hearing test, be intentionally inconsistent with button presses, especially in the left ear.
If the Stenger test is simulated, stop responding when the sound is louder in the 'bad' ear, even if it is audible in the 'good' ear.
Complain of ear pain to avoid pressure tests (tympanometry).
